ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES



Motiva Enterprises LLC - Dallas Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Dallas Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Dallas, TX. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.



Motiva Enterprises LLC (Motiva) - Dallas Terminal in Dallas, TX is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Motiva believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding EHS performance is of paramount importance.



The Dallas Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Motiva promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.



This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Motiva has designed and implemented, including:



A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;

B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;

C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;

D. An overview of the emergency response program; and

E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.



A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The primary function of the Dallas Terminal is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as Program level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes co

ntaining regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Motiva Enterprises LLC - Dallas Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees and contractors/visitors which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Dallas Terminal.



The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure (pressure reliefs set at 250 psi on the storage vessel). The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into regular and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truckloading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending/injection skid and auto-analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees fahrenheit) feeds to pneumatic valves (fail safe), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shut-off devices on the system and HMI, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Dallas Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.



B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC

PREVENTION MEASURES



Motiva's accidental release prevention programs along with emergency planning and response programs allow affective management of the hazards posed by Butane to our employees, the public, and the environment. Th

e covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the Dallas Terminal:



1) Employee Participation

2) Process Safety Information

3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) with Risk Assessments

4) Standard Operating Procedures

5) EHS and Operator Training

6) Contractors

7) Pre-startup Safety Review

8) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance

9) Work Permits

10) Management of Change

11) EHS Accident or Potential/Actual Catastrophic Event Investigation

12) Emergency Response

13) Compliance Audits

14) Trade Secrets



These fourteen (14) individual elements of the Dallas Terminal prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Motiva and its employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, Motiva also employs specific prevention measures that are incorporated into the process operating procedures and engineering and administrative controls to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and reduce the consequences of a release. These are briefly summarized as follows:



General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures include:



-Process is engineered and constructed (as a minimum) in accordance with recognized industry and company standards.

-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety/relief valves).

-Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process Flow Diagrams.

-Operating systems monitored and controlled by trained Operators along with third party "24/7" remote monitoring.

-Computerized monitoring and control of process operation.

-Redundant control systems.

-Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems.

-Scheduled inspection and testing of instruments, analyzers, and safety devices.

-Limited facility access.

-Regular

safety meetings and safety awareness programs.

-Routinely scheduled safety inspections and audits.

-Frequent unit surveillance by operators, and "24/7" remote monitoring.



General Release Mitigation includes:



-Automatic (ESD and thermal actuated) and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity.

-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks.

-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release with auto shutdown functions.



General Emergency Response includes:



-Emergency alert system.

-Periodic emergency training for employees.

-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies.

-Emergency drills with plant personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.



Further, the Dallas Terminal Butane Process complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58 [2014 at time of construction]) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department and City of Dallas Office of Emergency Management (Dallas County LEPC).



C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Dallas Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. As this is a new process, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials (Butane) covered under the EPA RMP regulation.



D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Response actions are coordinated with the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when

there is a need for a response.



Motiva - Dallas Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state and local laws and regulations. The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's (Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals, L.P.), instructions and recommendations.



In the event of an emergency involving the Dallas Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire response capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department and City of Dallas Office of Emergency Management (Dallas County LEPC). The Dallas Fire-Rescue Department regularly participates in training and exercise sessions for this Facility.



E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Motiva Enterprises, LLC is continually striving to make the Dallas Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community.



In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Motiva looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. The Dallas Fire-Rescue Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, Motiva works cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.
